title: How to Care for 5 Days Old Chicks #business #chicken #homesteading

tasks.task: Caring for young chicks in a brooding area.
subtasks: Checking and maintaining temperature of the brooding area (90-95°F or 30-32°C).
Ensuring the chicks have clean and fresh water at all times.
Monitoring the chicks' environment for proper ventilation to prevent ammonia buildup.
Cleaning the brooding area daily to prevent disease and odor buildup.
Providing appropriate feed (crumbles) for the chicks' age (five days old).
Observing chick behavior for signs of illness, such as labored breathing or diarrhea.
Checking for feather growth as a sign of development.
Ensuring the chicks have enough space to move around and are active.
Replacing treated paper or sawdust to maintain dryness and absorb moisture.
Checking water trays and refilling as needed to prevent the chicks from running out.
Monitoring the number of chicks (60-61) to ensure none have been overlooked or lost.
Providing crumb feed to the chicks.
Checking the feeding tray to ensure the chicks are eating the right amount.
Ensuring the water is clean and free from bacteria.
Refilling the water trays regularly.

tasks.task: Feeding and caring for baby chicks.
subtasks: Ensuring water is available at all times.
Monitoring and adjusting the brooding temperature.
Checking for signs of illness in the chicks.
Maintaining the cleanliness of the brooding area.
Observing chick behavior for normal activity.
Feeding appropriate crumb feed.
Replacing bedding materials like treated paper or sawdust.
Ensuring proper ventilation to prevent ammonia buildup.
Checking the chick count and addressing any missing chicks.
Refilling water pans and adjusting as needed.
Observing feather growth to monitor development.
Ensuring adequate water supply for the chicks.
Cleaning and replacing water pans as necessary.
Checking water levels frequently.
Using treated paper or sawdust to absorb moisture.
Replacing damp bedding materials regularly.
Ensuring the brooding area remains dry.
Deciding when to turn off lights based on daylight.
Using natural daylight as much as possible.
Supplementing with artificial light if needed.

tasks.task: Monitoring and adjusting brooding area size.
subtasks: Ensuring the brooder is not overcrowded.
Preparing to move chicks once space becomes an issue.
